properties.media:imagetext:
- 2 -
seem like the wheel
barrow which we just flew over.
I have always wanted
tO
see
a wheel barrow with a sail and just now I spied one going along a narrow road.
It
was headed the opposite direction from our route which is another way of expressing
the
aviators favorite complaint - i.e., we have a head wind.
However, when you are
bucking a head wind you usually fly low and that is how it happened that I saw the
wheel barrow with full rigged square
of this "Kansas Yacht"
sail.
The coolie who was acting as helmsman
was stepping along at a lively rate while four people sat on
the barrow - two on each side of the "keel".
The
sail was about five feet high by
four feet wide.
I have seen pictures of these contraptions but this is the first
one I have ever
seen in actual use.
The "captain" did not have to worry like the
old Cape Cod captain who said he would not sail a brig because he was a
good
Caristian and the bible directed that no good Christian "could serve two masters."
I had a fine rest at Peiping.
When I arrived found Frances,
Bo and Ruth
were away
on a trip to Tai
Yuan Iu, Capital
of Shansi Province.
Shansi means
"west of the mountains" while Shantung means "east of the mountains".
In that section
there had been heavy rains with reports in Peiping that the rivers were overflowing
their banks, many ci ties wiped out,
bandits on
the loose and the usual number of
rumors which
thrive and gain momentun in a country where transportation and
communication is so uncertain.
Debby was quite worried but Sunday we received a
very welcome if inelegant telegram "hold your noses here we come".
And sure
enough Sunday evening about 7:30 the girls descended on us with eighteen bundles
of loot gathered in Shansi,
the packages ranging in size fron small
boxes to good
sized Shansi chests.
If we had locked the bathroom doors, I think the girls would
have traded all their plunder for the keys.
After one day in Peiping, they started
off early Tuesday morning for a trip to the Diamond Mountains of Korea. It will be
another interesting experience for them, and I'm wondering what the hige light will
be.
On the lastirly it was gun fire. The girls were crossing a big plain in Shansi
when they heard a loud mizzing noise over head, often repeated. In the distance
they could hear rifly fire.
Finally it dawned on them that the whizzing sound
was caused by bullets and they proceded in true negro fashion to say "feet carry
me away".
It turnd out that they were crossing a rifle range and probably stood
a much better chance of getting hit than if they had been the targets.
We are all very sad over the thought of Ruth going home early in
Septerber .
She has been a moal addition to our party in China and we*ll miss her.
I imagine
there will be times during her debutant winter when some boring dimmer
partner will catch a far away look in her eye and never quite know what the score is,
but I know too that she will cary on in St. Louis as she has here taking things
good, bad and indifferent, making the most of them all.
Nearing Shanghai nor so will wind up this letter - as ever
Narolo
